The picture is not entirely a mix of reds and grays per se. If the image were composed entirely of red and gray, the red pixel values would always be greater than or equal to the blue and green values, and the blue and green values would be equal to each other. Red was never significantly lower than the green and blue for any pixel in the image. However, I ran the image through a program and found that 31% of the image has a significant difference (RGB value over 16) between the green and blue pixel values. So while the first condition was satisfied, the second was not. Thus, unless there was an error in saving the image, it would be more accurate to say the image is mostly red, with some magenta or orange/yellow.

Fun color fact: The color pink doesn't exist! It's merely an illusion, & a purely human one too! I mean, technically ALL color is an illusion because it's simply the way your brain interprets different wavelengths of light, but the other colors all have corresponding positions on the light spectrum... except for pink! There's no way for what we see as "pink" to exist. Using color theory, pink should correspond to a wavelength directly between red & white light, but... How? That shouldn't be possible. Pink is a color that, as far as we've been able to determine, only humans can perceive. Perhaps that's why pink is so often associated with love, romance, empathy... All very "human" emotions!

Nothing wrong with your eyes folks. This wasn't demonstrated properly. In fact, the more I think about it, the whole thing is wrong. I'm researching it right now for art purposes. In one Land experiment, he used one filter, BUT uses various wavelengths of light, including white. In  another experiment, Land uses two frequencies of yellow projected through black and white film. These combine to form colors that appear to be different than what appeared. Here, they used some photo manipulation (probably photoshop) thats not even close to what the experiment was.  The original experiment is with projectors.﻿

People need to understand something about the picture with the colors -- it's not a color blindness test, it's a proof of how our brain alters the actual colors our retina receives based on scene properties... None of these work on me ever. Even if I was not formally told about what the trick is. You can train yourself by first understanding how people "read" colors. If to you the reds look green it is because it has been pulled to the green side slightly. It is being pulled to he neutral core (grey) which is the color you get when you mix every color including white and black. It appears green because of directly varying contrast, the same thing with the dots, Christmas colors, and the Raven's. :)

Because of that, the color 'green' could be grey or similar, and thus the grey in the image could be orange or green or rainbow colored.

That, or because the title said "This is Only Red", your brain already knew that it had to be some type of red. This made it eliminate "green", due to the fact it looks nothing alike red, and may have made the "orange" look like red or pink. This is known as the Placebo Effect.

Take a look at the picture on 0:53.

There are 3 things that affect color; hue, brightness, and saturation.

The hue is the actual color, Up and down is the brightness of an image. Left and right is the saturation.

When the brightness is at 100, the color is white. When the brightness is 0, it's black. 100 and 0 will never have any saturation.

When the saturation is 100, it is the absolute color of the hue(EX. red). When it is 0, the color must be somewhere in between black and white.

Consider a view in front of you that is 90 degrees by 90 degrees, like looking through an open window at a scene. The number of pixels would be 
90 degrees * 60 arc-minutes/degree * 1/0.3 * 90 * 60 * 1/0.3 = 324,000,000 pixels (324 megapixels).
 Let's be conservative and use 120 degrees for the field of view. Then we would see
120 * 120 * 60 * 60 / (0.3 * 0.3) = 576 megapixels.

I think I might be able to explain why everyone only sees red even thought we're supposed to see blues and yellows.... In the science of colours, there's something called Simultaneous Contrast: when a colour is placed next to a grey, the grey will take a shade of the opposed colour on the chromatic circle (for example, next to a red, the grey looks green.) The thing is, this contrast doesn't work on a computer because it's about reflected light, not projected, so it has to be on paper to work.

There are actually different varieties of colorblindness. That could be one variety, but a weird one is where you don't see one type of color or another. This is actually the same type of colorblindness dogs have, though to a more extreme degree. They see everything but blue as yellow, and they see blue as blue. What he meant with "only red" is that the _hue_ is red (or undefined). In other words, any color between black, red and white.  For example, a pink halfway between red and white (R = 100%, G = 50%, B = 50%) has still a red hue. 
In the R-G-B color space, it's the triangular surface where G=B and R > G.
